channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Taiwan Is Both Exhilarated and Unnerved by Trump’s China Remarks
item.media:description: Lin Fei-fan, a protest leader, in Taipei, Taiwan. He is excited by President-elect Donald J. Trump’s apparent willingness to rethink the One China policy, but also anxious: “We are suspicious of his motivations.”
item.media:credit: An Rong Xu for The New York Times
item.description: The president-elect’s apparent willingness to rethink the principle that prioritizes China over Taiwan has energized many, but some fear being used as a bargaining chip.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ and AMY QIN

item.title: China Suggests It Has Placed Weapons on Disputed Spratly Islands in South China Sea
item.description: China’s plan to strengthen its claims over the islands has raised tensions with neighbors and the United States over freedom of navigation in the South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Center for Strategic and International Studies

item.title: U.S. Halts Aid Package to Philippines Amid Drug Crackdown
item.media:description: A police raid in Manila in October. A crackdown on drugs under President Rodrigo Duterte has led to the deaths of thousands of people, many at the hands of the police.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The decision reflected “significant concerns around the rule of law and civil liberties,” a spokeswoman for the American Embassy said.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Aleppo Evacuation Suspended After 8,000 People Removed
item.media:description: Syrians were evacuated from a rebel-held area of eastern Aleppo on Friday.
item.description: Syrian activists reported hearing explosions near the gathering point for those seeking to leave, and the state news media accused rebel fighters of firing on convoys of evacuees.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Egypt Says Traces of Explosives Were Found on Bodies From Paris Flight
item.description: The announcement offered the strongest suggestion yet that a bomb might have brought down the airliner in May.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Germany Didn’t Know Migrant Held in Killing Had Violent Past in Greece
item.media:description: The Hohenasperg prison hospital in Asperg, Germany, where the Afghan suspect in the case of a murdered medical student has been transferred.
item.description: The news about an Afghan asylum seeker raised concerns about Europe’s ability to enforce laws within the 26 countries that allow for free cross-border travel.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: What E.U. Leaders Are Wrestling With at the End of a Tough Year
item.media:description: From left: Prime Minister Charles Michel of Belgium; President François Hollande of France; Jean-Claude Juncker, president of the European Commission; and Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece at the European Union summit meeting in Brussels on Thursday.
item.description: Officials tiptoed through a geopolitical minefield as they gathered in Brussels for their end-of-year summit meeting. Here’s a guide to the thorniest issues.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Talks Could Stretch 10 Years, British Official Warns
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain arrived at the European Union summit in Brussels on Thursday.
item.description: Britain seems to still be struggling to devise a coherent discussion plan as the deadline approaches to start negotiations to leave the European Union.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Mexican Report Says Investigators Botched Search for 43 Students
item.media:description: In April, members of the families of 43 college students who disappeared in 2014 and their supporters marched in Mexico City.
item.description: A review that the government refuses to release found that suspects had been arrested and moved illegally, jeopardizing any criminal case in the 2014 disappearance.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: The Boy, the Ambassador and the Deadly Encounter on the Road
item.media:description: Toussaint Birwe, 6, was hit by an S.U.V. traveling in a motorcade for Samantha Power, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, in Mokong, Cameroon.
item.description: The cheers in a Cameroonian village, as an armored convoy of American officials passed through, turned to anger when a child was struck and killed.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: What in the World: Napping in Public? In Japan, That’s a Sign of Diligence
item.media:description: Sleeping in public is especially prevalent on commuter trains, no matter how crowded, in Japan. It helps that the country has a very low crime rate.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: The practice of “inemuri,” or “sleeping while present,” is common. People sleep on the job, but also in cafes and on commuter trains.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Beijing, Bracing for 5 Days of Heavy Pollution, Issues Red Alert
item.media:description: Heavy smog blanketed Beijing on Friday, moving in from the industrial heartland of surrounding Hebei Province.
item.description: The most severe notice in a four-tier system requires schools to close and half of all privately owned cars to stay off the roads.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Meeting Between Japan and Russia Ends With Stalemate on Disputed Islands
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe during a welcome ceremony for the Russian leader in Tokyo on Friday. A dispute over four islands has prevented Japan and Russia from signing a peace treaty ending World War II.
item.description: The talks between President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan yielded little, other than details of business deals that had already been announced.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Sinosphere: China Has Made Strides in Addressing Air Pollution, Environmentalist Says
item.media:description: The Qian’an steelworks of the Shougang Corporation in Tangshan, a leading steel manufacturing city in China, in January.
item.description: Ma Jun notes progress in acknowledging the scope of the problem, despite continuing constraints on public discussion that might stir social unrest.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: E.U. Reaches Compromise With the Netherlands on Closer Ukraine Ties
item.media:description: “I am going to fight to get a majority” in Parliament, said Prime Minister Mark Rutte of the Netherlands. “We will have to see. It won’t be easy. We’ll have to work hard for it.”
item.description: The Dutch had been the lone holdout among European Union member nations on an association agreement that would seek to counter Russia’s influence in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Russia Turns Over American Cybertheft Suspect to the U.S.
item.description: The decision was seen by some as an effort to tamp down criticism over Russian meddling in the American presidential campaign on behalf of Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: ‘It’s Like a Miracle’: Woman Gives Birth Using Ovary Frozen Since Childhood
item.media:description: Moaza al-Matrooshi with her husband, Ahmed, and their newborn son. Doctors said the birth could pave the way for restoring fertility to women who suffer cancer and other illnesses at an early age.
item.description: Tissue from the cryogenically preserved ovary of a child who was 9 was reimplanted in her 14 years later and she was able to conceive.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Paris Journal: Rodents Run Wild in Paris. Blame the European Union.
item.media:description: Nine parks and green spaces in Paris have been closed either partly or entirely because of a rat problem.
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.description: Rat invasion is an old problem in Paris, and also a new one. New methods of poisoning the creatures aren’t working so well.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Sinosphere: Don’t Call It ‘Smog’ in Beijing, Call It a ‘Meteorological Disaster’
item.media:description: A woman wore a mask against air pollution in Beijing on Monday.
item.description: City officials are poised to legally classify air pollution as a weather calamity, like a sandstorm, worrying those who see it as a way to dodge responsibility.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Ruling Paves Way for Transfer of Art Trove Including Nazi-Looted Works
item.media:description: Some of the roughly 1,500 artworks Cornelius Gurlitt kept for years in his Munich apartment.
item.media:credit: Staatsanwaltschaft Augsburg, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The German owner of the 1,500 artworks was of sound mind when he bequeathed them to a museum in Switzerland, a court in Munich ruled.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY and ALISON SMALE

item.title: Aleppo Evacuation Effort Restarts, and Assad Calls It History in the Making
item.media:description: An older man was evacuated from a rebel-held neighborhood of Aleppo, Syria, on Thursday.
item.description: Some 3,000 people were evacuated from the remaining rebel-held districts of Aleppo, and President Bashar al-Assad claimed a great victory.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Only a Rumbling Volcano Could Make North Korea and the West Play Nice
item.media:description: Mount Paektu, on the border between North Korea and China, erupted 1,000 years ago in one of the most violent volcanic explosions in human history.
item.description: Mount Paektu is sacred to the North Korean people. When a swarm of tiny earthquakes were recorded, the reclusive country decided it needed help.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Dear America, Why Did You Let Us Down?
item.media:description: Air Force One at Joint Base Andrews, Md., this month.
item.description: To the rest of the world, the election of Donald Trump feels like a sudden plunge after a gradual decline.
item.dc:creator: LISA PRYOR

item.title: On Campus: American Universities in a Gulf of Hypocrisy
item.media:description: On the campus of New York University Abu Dhabi. The failure of Georgetown and N.Y.U. to call out the suppression of critical speech suggests the complicity that gulf money buys.
item.description: By soft-pedaling criticism of their Qatari and Emirati paymasters, U.S. schools are compromising academic freedom.
item.dc:creator: KRISTINA BOGOS

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: No, Settlers Don’t Control Israeli Politics
item.media:description: An Israeli family in the Jewish settlement Amona in the West Bank this month.
item.description: If they did, why would the government be preparing to evacuate a hilltop outpost in the West Bank?
item.dc:creator: SHMUEL ROSNER

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
